abstracts.cdata!:
The Bo Hai Sea is a semi-enclosed
            international sea located in the northwest corner of the
            yellow sea. It has globally important ecological resources
            and provides significant fishery benefits to China, North
            and South Korea, Japan, and Taiwan. Fish and shellfish stock
            in the yellow sea are dependent on the Bo Hai Sea as a
            reproduction and nursery area. Currently, the Bo Hai Sea is
            under considerable stress. Pollution, the reduction of
            freshwater inflows, overfishing and habitat loss has
            diminished its ecosystem functions. The most seriously
            affected areas include the estuaries and coastal areas. A
            lack of effective pollution control for surface and
            groundwater draining into the Bo Hai Sea has contributed to
            mass mortality of aquaculture species and an increasing
            frequency of harmful algal blooms known as 'red
            tides.' The project's overall objective is to
            revive the Bo Hai Sea environment with an integrated
            approach to water resources management and pollution control
            in the Hai river basin. It is designed to improve integrated
            water and environment planning and management, provide the
            necessary institutional support and capacity building, and
            reduce municipal wastewater discharges into the Bo Hai Sea.
            The project also serves as a link to water and environmental
            management issues for two World Bank-financed operations in
            the Hai Basin: the Second Tianjin Urban Environment and
            Development Project, and the Water Conservation Project.
